hints_html:
Start with the substitution \(u = \sqrt{x}\)

There are two techniques to reduce the order of the derivative under the integral: integration by parts and the fundamental theorem of calculus. You want to use both, in the right order.
hints_latex:
There are two techniques to reduce the order of the derivative under the
integral: integration by parts and the fundamental theorem of calculus.
You want to use both, in the right order.
hints_raw:
Start with the substitution <math> u = \sqrt{x} </math>
There are two techniques to reduce the order of the derivative under the integral: integration by parts and the fundamental theorem of calculus. You want to use both, in the right order.
question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
We begin evaluating this integral by making a change of variable to deal with the square root:

\[\begin{aligned} u = \sqrt{x} \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}\,dx = \frac{1}{2u}\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

And hence,

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{4}f''(\sqrt{x})\,dx = 2\int_{0}^{2}uf''(u)\,du.\end{aligned}\]

Now using integration by parts we evaluate the integral. Let \(\displaystyle v=u\) and \(\displaystyle dw = f''(u)\,du\) so that we have \(\displaystyle dv = du\) and \(\displaystyle w = f'(u)\) (which holds by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus as \(\displaystyle f'(u)\) is an antiderivative of \(\displaystyle f''(u)\). Thus

\[\begin{aligned} 2\int_{0}^{2}uf''(u)\,du &= 2\left(uf'(u) \Big\vert_{0}^{2} - \int_{0}^{2}f'(u)\,du \right) \end{aligned}\]

Now, we once again use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and note that \(\displaystyle f(u)\) is an antiderivative of \(\displaystyle f'(u)\) and this gives

\[\begin{aligned} 2\left(uf'(u) \Big\vert_{0}^{2} - \int_{0}^{2}f'(u)\,du \right) &= 2\left( uf'(u) - f(u) \right) \Big\vert_{0}^{2} \\ &= 2\left( 2f'(2) - f(2) + f(0) \right)\end{aligned}\]

Plugging the values of the terms given in the statement of the question gives:

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue}\int_{0}^{4}f''(\sqrt{x})\,dx = 2\left(2(4) - 3 + 1 \right) =12.}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We begin evaluating this integral by making a change of variable to deal
with the square root:

\begin{align*}
u = \sqrt{x} \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}\,dx = \frac{1}{2u}\,dx.
\end{align*}
And hence,

\begin{align*}
\int_{0}^{4}f''(\sqrt{x})\,dx = 2\int_{0}^{2}uf''(u)\,du.
\end{align*} Now using
integration by parts we evaluate the integral. Let $\displaystyle v=u$
and $\displaystyle dw = f''(u)\,du$ so that we have
$\displaystyle dv = du$ and $\displaystyle w = f'(u)$ (which holds by
the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus as $\displaystyle f'(u)$ is an
antiderivative of $\displaystyle f''(u)$. Thus

\begin{align*}
2\int_{0}^{2}uf''(u)\,du &= 2\left(uf'(u) \Big\vert_{0}^{2} - \int_{0}^{2}f'(u)\,du \right) 
\end{align*} Now, we once again use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
and note that $\displaystyle f(u)$ is an antiderivative of
$\displaystyle f'(u)$ and this gives

\begin{align*}
2\left(uf'(u) \Big\vert_{0}^{2} - \int_{0}^{2}f'(u)\,du \right) &= 2\left( uf'(u) - f(u) \right) \Big\vert_{0}^{2} \\
&= 2\left( 2f'(2) - f(2) + f(0) \right)
\end{align*} Plugging the values of the terms given in the statement of
the question gives:

\begin{align*}
{\color{blue}\int_{0}^{4}f''(\sqrt{x})\,dx = 2\left(2(4) - 3 + 1 \right) =12.}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We begin evaluating this integral by making a change of variable to deal with the square root:
:<math>
u = \sqrt{x} \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}\,dx = \frac{1}{2u}\,dx.
</math>
And hence,
:<math>
\int_{0}^{4}f''(\sqrt{x})\,dx = 2\int_{0}^{2}uf''(u)\,du.
</math>
Now using integration by parts we evaluate the integral. Let <math>\displaystyle v=u</math> and <math> \displaystyle dw = f''(u)\,du</math> so that we have <math> \displaystyle dv = du</math> and <math> \displaystyle w = f'(u)</math> (which holds by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus as <math> \displaystyle f'(u)</math> is an antiderivative of <math> \displaystyle f''(u)</math>. Thus
:<math>
\begin{align}
2\int_{0}^{2}uf''(u)\,du &= 2\left(uf'(u) \Big\vert_{0}^{2} - \int_{0}^{2}f'(u)\,du \right) 
\end{align}
</math>
Now, we once again use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and note that <math> \displaystyle f(u)</math> is an antiderivative of <math> \displaystyle f'(u)</math> and this gives
:<math>
\begin{align}
2\left(uf'(u) \Big\vert_{0}^{2} - \int_{0}^{2}f'(u)\,du \right) &= 2\left( uf'(u) - f(u) \right) \Big\vert_{0}^{2} \\
&= 2\left( 2f'(2) - f(2) + f(0) \right)
\end{align}
</math>
Plugging the values of the terms given in the statement of the question gives:
:<math>
{\color{blue}\int_{0}^{4}f''(\sqrt{x})\,dx = 2\left(2(4) - 3 + 1 \right) = 12.}
</math>
